table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: be gigantic, be huge, be humongous

table.name: mem
table.column: When this verb is applied to a person, it suggests an improvement in health. When it is applied to an inanimate object, it implies improvement or betterment. It is distinguished from {tI':v} because that verb is not usually applied to living beings, and suggests a restoration to a previous state and not improvement. It also differs from {Dub:v} in that that verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no single term for "nurse" in Klingon. Other possible terms for a doctor's assistant are {Qel boQ@@Qel:n:1h, boQ:n:1h} (or {HaqwI' boQ@@HaqwI':n, boQ:n:1h} if the doctor is a surgeon) and {QelHom:n:nolink}.[1]
Nurse "Ratch"ed, from "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

table.name: mem
table.column: Raggedy Ann is a popular doll.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of food made from live serpent worms (not to be confused with {qagh:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Rajma is red kidney bean curry.

table.name: mem
table.column: be trivial, be trifling, be unimportant, be insignificant
This was defined as "be trivial, be trifling, be unimportant" in {TKD:src}, and as "be insignificant" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The opposite of this is {pem:n}, not {jaj:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Avian life-form indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} that only comes out in the dark.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "be in charge of, have authority over". It would be weird for this verb to be used without an object. There is some overlap in meaning with {ngoy':v}.[2]
be in charge of, have authority over

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of {rap:v:nolink} are the things which are the same.[2]
This verb can also be used to express the concept that two things have the same amount of some quality. The verb {nIb:v} is used similarly, but it is usually used with measurable qualities and has the connotation of preciseness. However, it is not improper to use {rap:v:nolink} with a quality that is measurable. See the examples below.[3]
▶ {ghun 'Iw HIq, rap boqrat chej.} "The bokrat liver is as warm as the bloodwine."[3] ▶ {'ey ro'qegh'Iwchab, rap qagh.} "The gagh is as delicious as the rokeg blood pie."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Star-Spangled Banner has the phrase "o'er the ramparts we watched", and {rapmar:n:nolink} reversed sounds like "rampart".

table.name: mem
table.column: This indicates that something is a repeat or an extra of something else. It can be used to describe the concept of {bIraqlul:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This can be applied to the arts, weapons, or spaceships. It refers to any activity which involves having some control over some object. In the context of swords, it can be used with a similar meaning to {yan:v}. In the context of spaceships (see {Duj:n:1}), this refers to controlling a vessel "manually", rather than by computer.[1, p.79]
In contrast to {ruQ:v:nolink}, which is more likely to be used when the handling alters the configuration of the thing being manipulated, {raQ:v:nolink} is used when the thing being handled doesn't do anything if it's not being handled. {raQ:v:nolink} is used when manually controlling a spaceship using switches or buttons and so on, as opposed to letting the computer control things automatically. But {ruQ:v:nolink} would be used if someone is manually controlling the thrusters by physically doing something to them directly, like yanking a thruster component, or twisting something, or banging on something.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: When stapling papers together (see {Ha'on vevwI':n}), the papers are the object of {rar:v:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means the subjects are generally or conceptually related.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that each floor, or level, on a vessel is called a {choQ:n} (deck).
There is a Klingon idiom, {'IQ; rav rur@@'IQ:v, rav:n:1, rur:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: It's unclear why {rav:n:2,nolink} seems to follow the noun while {'aqroS:n:2,nolink} seems to precede the noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to express the idea of some (perhaps unknown) point between two ends of a range. To express the full stretch of the entire range, use {qubbID:n} instead.[1]

▶ {QujwI' ghom rav:sen:nolink}: {cha'; 'aqroS:sen:nolink}: {jav:sen:nolink} "2 to 6 players"[2] ▶ {rav cha' 'uj(mey) 'aqroS loS 'uj(mey) 'ab:sen@@rav ...:sen, cha':n:num, 'uj:n, -mey:n, 'aqroS ...:sen, loS:n:1,num, 'uj:n, -mey:n, 'ab:v} "has a length between two and four ujes" (it's at least two ujes and no more than four)[1] ▶ {rav DaSjaj 'aqroS buqjaj maghom:sen@@rav:n:2, DaSjaj:n, 'aqroS:n:2, buqjaj:n, ma-:v, ghom:v} "we meet between Monday and Friday", "we meet at some point between Monday and Friday"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to stand-alone (moveable) furniture only, not something built-in.
Feodor Ingvar Kamprad was the founder of the IKEA furniture company.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to the ceiling ({'aqroS:n:1}) of a room that has a room above it. The ceiling of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure is called its {pa' beb:n}.[2]
The first element of this word is {rav:n:1} "floor", but the second element is unrelated to {'eq:v} "be early".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this is a verb in Klingon. In Klingon, one says "it lightnings", similar to how one says "it rains" in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: an aquatic bird with colorful plumage

table.name: mem
table.column: A geneticist would presumably be a {raytej:n}, though it's unclear what the root {ray:n:hyp,nolink} means.
Gene "R"oddenberry. Also, {ray:n} may be an abbrevation for {roSghaH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction based on {rayQeD:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is intended for use by people, whereas a {HuDyar:n} is typically used for storing things, although there is overlap between them.
The groundskeeper at Starfleet Academy, Boothby, was portrayed by Ray Walston.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call Terran rice.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a triangle where each interior angle is 40.5 {lawmey:n:nolink}, or 60 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink}. (See {law:n} and {lawrI':n}.)
For other polygons with equal sides/angles, {HoS:v} is used instead of {tIQ:v:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not defined, but its meaning is clear from the example and from {ra'ghomquv:n:nolink}.

▶ {tera' jar Soch, DIS wa' Hut jav Hut, maSDaq SaqmeH Qu' wa'DIch HochHom turlu'taHvIS, wej logh lengwI'pu' pa'mey 'oH Apollo wa'maH wa' ra'ghom bobcho' Columbia'e'.:sen:nolink} "The Apollo 11 Command Module, 'Columbia,' was the living quarters for the three-person crew during most of the first manned lunar landing mission in July 1969."

table.name: mem
table.column: The High Command runs the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drink made from liquor added to coffee. Its name may have originated as a contraction of {ra'wI' taj:n:nolink}. An "export" version called "raktajino", popular in the Federation, is not alcoholic, but has added flavour.[1, p.96]

table.name: mem
table.column: commander (any officer of rank {Sogh:n:nolink} or higher)

This refers to someone of rank {Sogh:n} or higher, and may be used either as a description or a title.[2]
Do not confuse this with {la':n}, which is also translated as "commander" in English.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Retch". Also, the words for inhale and exhale together sound like "poor wretch" ({pur rech:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: In geometry, this word refers to the side of a polygon.[1]
In the geometry usage, this word's only appearance in canon has been between a number and one of {mey':n} or {'Impey':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an extension of {reD:n:1} to refer to an object's surface which is not the top, bottom, front, or back. In this context, the front of the object is its {logh'ob:n:2} and the back is its {Sa'Hut:n:2}.[1; 2]
Even when applied to a person or an animal, this doesn't take the suffix {-Du':n:suff}, because it refers to an area and not a specific body part. This word does not mean "side" in the sense of one of two opposite directions such as "left" and "right" or "top" and "bottom", for which see {Dop:n}.[3]

An explanation of {logh'ob:n:2,nolink}, {Sa'Hut:n:2,nolink}, and {reD:n:3,nolink} was given during the Q & A session at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}.
This was defined as "side". The clarification "exterior surface" was added based on the explanation, and to differentiate it from {Dop:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Backwards of "(Darth) Vader". Another word for "shortage" is "dearth".

table.name: mem
table.column: The slang expression {pumnuj reD'eS:n@@pumnuj:n, reD'eS:n} is used if things are definitely inefficient.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Romulan Star Empire.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tun; reghuluS 'Iwghargh rur@@tun:v, reghuluS 'Iwghargh:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Sometimes, it may be appropriate to use {-taH:v:suff} (without {reH:adv}) to translate "always". For example, see {Duj tIvoqtaH.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: The difference between this and {Quj:v} is that this refers to unstructured play, whereas {Quj:v:nolink} refers to structured play. This verb does not take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The used kut'luch is always shiny.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your father is a part of you always.

table.name: mem
table.column: Always it is the brave ones who die.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you always find a bloodworm in your glass!

table.name: mem
table.column: reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj puS.
The fire is always hotter on someone else's face.

table.name: mem
table.column: A Klingon warrior is always prepared to fight.

table.name: mem
table.column: A great warrior is always prepared.

table.name: mem
table.column: One is always of his tribe.

table.name: mem
table.column: May the Klingon Empire continue forever.

table.name: mem
table.column: I will remember this dinner forever.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to underwear in general. To be more specific, say {rejghun yopwaH bID:n@@rejghun:n, yopwaH bID:n}, etc.
"Reg Grundies" is Australian slang for underwear.

table.name: mem
table.column: He was a follower of {tIquvma:n:name} who was given the role of {Sech qengwI':n}. He was the brother of {'or'eq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means dazed in the sense of confused, unable to think properly, bewildered.[1] It means delusional, in this sense.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears to be composed from {rem:v} and {'ay':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used to describe the design of a physical object of some sort; it would not be used in the sense of making a plan to do something (which would be {nab:v}). It differs from {'ogh:v}, which implies the creation of something which has not been created before.
Christopher Wren and James Renwick, Jr., were the names of two famous architects.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen} for some ways to tell time.
▶ {rep yIper!:sen} (to ask for the time in the Federation system, see {tera' poH:n}) ▶ {tera' rep cha':sen:nolink} or {rep cha':sen:nolink} "two o'clock" (in the Federation system)

table.name: mem
table.column: A slang way to say this is {ghaw':n:3}.

table.name: mem
table.column: One can say either {tlheH reS@@tlheH:n, reS:v:1} or just {reS:sen:nolink} for "he/she casts a spell". It's unclear if anything other than {tlheH:n} can be the object of {reS:v:1,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the plant which is grown by the subject.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
If it's necessary to make a distinction between shin and forearm, this word can be preceded by {'uS:n} or {DeS:n:1}.
This refers to the front of the lower leg, whereas the entire lower part of the leg would be {'uS cha'neH:n@@'uS:n, cha'neH:n}.
The only way Maltz was aware of to refer to the shin bone is {reStav Hom:n@@reStav:n, Hom:n:1}.
The Hebrew letter "shin" comes between the letters "resh" and "tav".

table.name: mem
table.column:
A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the past for the following units: ▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {Hu':n} "days ago" ▶ {jar:n} "month" - {wen:n} "months ago" ▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {ben:n:1} "years ago"
For other units of time, {ret:n:nolink} is used.[1]
This is the same word as the verb {ret:v}.[2]
▶ {cha' tup ret:n@@cha':n, tup:n, ret:n} "two minutes ago"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the same word as the noun {ret:n}.

▶ {cha' tup ret jIQuch:sen:nolink} "Two minutes ago, I was happy." ▶ {qaStaHvIS cha' tup ret jIQuch:sen:nolink} "I was happy during the past (that is, most recent) two minutes." or "...for the past two minutes." or "... over the past two minutes." ▶ {qep'a' ret:n:nolink} "the most recent {qep'a':sen:nolink}"

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not refer to how to format a paragraph.

table.name: mem
table.column: To be more specific, one can use {tlhop:n:1}, {'em:n}, {poS:n}, or {nIH:n}. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for citing the speech or writing of someone else.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the action of alternately squeezing and stretching out the bag part of the {may'ron:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This noun refers to a performance or presentation that's pretty special in some way. Maybe it's something that happens only once, not to be repeated. Or maybe it occurs regularly but not very often, so it's something which is looked forward to well in advance. Maybe it's something that features a special performer or performers.[1]
The KLI Cabaret is a special performance which takes place at the {qep'a':n} (making it a {qep'a' rey':n:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to be spread out like a deck of cards fanned on a table or peanut butter on a piece of bread.
A rib spreader is a surgical implement for thoracic surgery.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of the verb is the topic of discussion.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was requested specifically to translate "Prime Directive".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the process that food goes through.

table.name: mem
table.column: One first charges up ({Huj:v:2,t}) a device before energizing ({rIH:v:nolink}) it.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {Sen:v:1} instead.
The reflexive form of this verb has a special meaning. See the example below, and under {SIq:v} for an explanation.
This is a reference to the nursery rhyme "Little Jack Horner" (see {rIl:v:2}).
▶ {nujDajDaq rIl'egh ghu.:sen:nolink} "The baby sucks its thumb."

table.name: mem
table.column: The usage of this verb is restricted to the {gheb:n}, while {SuS:v} is a more general term that applies to all wind instruments.

This is a reference to the nursery rhyme "Little Jack Horner" (see {rIl:v:1}).
{gheb rIl:sen:nolink} is a reference to the horn of Gabriel.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {SenwI':n} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: It was confirmed during the Q & A session at {qep'a'2 27 (2020):src} that this is not grammatically considered a body part.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used with the suffix {-taH:v} to form {rIntaH:v}, a construction used to indicate finality (cf. the suffix {-ta':v}).[1]
By itself, {rIn:v:nolink} is used in radio transmissions to indicate end of transmission, similar to "over".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This special verbal construction follows another verb to indicate that the action described by the preceding verb is a fait accompli. It is similar in meaning to the verb suffix {-ta':v:suff}, but has the additional connotation of finality.

table.name: mem
table.column: This would apply to a scientific breakthrough or discovery, but not to, say, setting a new record in a bat'leth twirling competition.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence from {Klingon Monopoly:src} implies that this can mean "be damaged", when applied to non-living things.
▶ {Dumer DIvI' QaS 'ej DuHIv, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIrIQchoH.:sen:nolink} "Surprise attack by Federation leaves you unprotected and damaged."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: make a cracking, snapping, or clicking sound, emit a signal

This word originally referred only to emitting sound. Later, the meaning was extended to mean emitting any sort of signal: sound, radiation, smell, etc. In comparison, {tlhuD:v} refers only to the emission of radiation.

Snap, Crackle, Pop are the cartoon mascots of Rice Krispies, a breakfast cereal.
At {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, the definition included only "a cracking and snapping sound". At {qep'a' 28 (2021):src}, this was expanded to include "clicking".
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}, [3] {qep'a' 28 (2021):src}

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {rIS tlhen:sen@@rIS:n, tlhen:v} "(it) produces a click sound"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DurIt tlhIngan yejquv.:sen:nolink} "Summoned to the Klingon High Council."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is no noun in Klingon meaning "color".[1, p.81]
This also refers to ink, as for a rubber stamp ({toqwIn:n}).[2]
"Ritz" is a brand of paint or dye.

table.name: mem
table.column: For example, this is what an ax does to a watermelon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was defined only as "hail". The "communication" clarification was added to distinguish it from the weather phenomenon ({Heq:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "trunk (of body)" in {TKD:src} and glossed as "torso" in the text of {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to an imaginary line around which an object spins or is symmetrically arranged.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be the object of {naj:v} "dream" or {SIQ:v} "endure" and some other verbs, but generally not {ghaj:v} "have" (unless you somehow literally possess a nightmare).

William Shatner played a character named Robert Wilson in the Twilight Zone episode "Nightmare at 20,000 Feet".
One of the tracks on the Robin Williams comedy album "Reality... What a Concept" is named "Shakespeare (A Meltdowner's Nightmare)", but this is probably a genuine concidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: Dennis Gabor was the inventor of holography.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a dimension within a coordinate system, not another dimension like in a parallel universe (for which see {'u' quq:n} and {'u' Dop:n}).

Rod Serling's opening narrations (of which there are several) for the TV show "The Twilight Zone" all refer to entering or traveling through another dimension. For example: "You are about to enter another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind."

table.name: mem
table.column: Informally, the term {tlhepwI':n} is often used.[1]
Backwards of "nose door". One of the functions of the uvula is to close off the nasopharynx when swallowing.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to hair on the face which covers the chin and neck area.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is also used by Klingon grammarians to refer to the rule that governs the use of pronominal prefixes, a rule Federation grammarians call "agreement".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is considered too potent for tourists.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {matlhHa'; romuluSngan rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {HoHwI':n} for short.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Zn and atomic number 30.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In the context of playing dice, this word refers to the action of the dice as they are rolling. (To "throw" or "roll" the dice would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.)[1]
When applied to a person, it means the person is rolling haphazardly. To perform a somersault is {Hay:v}, and to roll down a hill (like a log) is {tetlh:v}.[2]
This verb can be applied to aircraft, for which see {ron:v:2}.

▶ {mI' naghmey tIronmoH:sen:nolink} "throw dice"[1] ▶ {ron SuvwI'; chorgh 'ujmey lID:sen@@ron:v:1, SuvwI':n, chorgh:n:1, 'uj:n, -mey:n, lID:v} or {chorgh 'ujmey lID SuvwI'; ron:sen@@chorgh:n:1, 'uj:n, -mey:n, lID:v, SuvwI':n, ron:v:1} "the warrior rolled (haphazardly) for eight ujes"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: roll (aircraft wings tilt, one up, one down)
This is just the verb {ron:v:1} applied to aircraft. For a pilot to roll an aircraft would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.
The aile"ron"s control the roll on an airplane.
▶ {ron muD Duj; javmaH lawrI'mey lID:sen@@ron:v:2, muD Duj:n, jav:n:1, maH:n:2, lawrI':n, -mey:n, lID:v} "the airplane rolled 60 degrees"

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used generally, not just for how Terrans tend to ruin food.[1]
This is preparing food in the "wrong" way, from a Klingon point of view.

table.name: mem
table.column: Diseases are referred to by the name for the disease followed by {rop:n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any epidemic, and not specifically the infectious disease caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis.
This word was not given a definition in isolation, and appears only as a component of {ruDelya' rop'a':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a scar which is the result of some sort of disease, infection, etc.
This was defined as just "scar", with an accompanying explanation of the kinds of scars.

table.name: mem
table.column: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This implies bulk due to body fat or the like, while {pI':v} does not have this connotation. Both can be used to express "not thin", but {ror:v:nolink} is more appropriate to convey "not lean". When this verb is used to describe an inanimate object, there is usually a bit of anthropomorphizing, likening the object to a person or an animal.[2]
A "fat book" would be a {paq qargh:n@@paq:n:1, qargh:v}, unless the book comes to life as a character in a cartoon or something like that. (In that case, the plural suffix {-pu':n:suff} might also be expected.)[2]
This was defined as just "be fat" in {TKD:src}. The clarification was added at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is "be fantastic" in the fantasy sense; it does not mean "be wonderful, terrific".[1]
The concept of a "fairy tale" might be expressed as {puq lut:n@@puq:n, lut:n} or {lut rorgh:n@@lut:n, rorgh:v} or {puq lut rorgh:n@@puq:n, lut:n, rorgh:v}.[2]
Ricardo Montalbán (Khan Noonien Singh) played Mr. Roarke on the TV series Fantasy Island.

table.name: mem
table.column: This little piggy had roast beef.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a slang term based on {roS:v:1} or {roS:v:2} meaning {qIS:v}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {HQ 10.2:src}[3], this verb consists of three elements: the verb {roS:v:3,is,hyp}, {-Ha':v}, and {-moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This little piggy had roast beef.

table.name: mem
table.column:
"He licks", helix.
It was confirmed during the Q & A session at {qep'a'2 27 (2020):src} that this is not grammatically considered a body part.

table.name: mem
table.column: Chromosomes are numbered (e.g., {roSmaH wej:n:nolink}). The two sex chromosomes are {roSmaH pagh:n:nolink} and {roSmaH bID:n:nolink}. Two {roSmaH bID:n:nolink} chromosomes occur in females, and one of each occur in males.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The game "rock-paper-scissors" is also known as "roshambo", and "rock" is basically a fist.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression is used to challenge someone to take action in a manner consistent with something he or she just said. (It's similar to the English expression "put your money where your mouth is".)
challenge, put your money where your mouth is

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "if the open hand becomes a fist". It is used in a similar fashion to the English expression "on the other hand".

table.name: mem
table.column: One of its ingredients is the {DayquS:n} plant.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Possibly a reference to a specific politician, though the resemblance might just be a genuine coincidence.
The original request wasn't neutral: "A person who is professionally involved in politics. Also a derogatory term for a person who manipulates or pleases others just to gain own advantage. For example, Gowron is described as a politician in DS9." Based on this, it seems the term may be used in a derogatory manner, to mean something like "political careerist" or "political opportunist".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This was used with an object in {Hamlet:src}.
This was used for "Ok" (while {qIl:v} was used for "Cancel") in Klingon Blockly.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz asserts that Klingons never blush.
This was confirmed as intransitive during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: be physical (subject to laws of physics)
This means that something is subject to the laws of physics; it could be applied to something corporeal but also to energy.[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: From the children's rhyme, a teapot is "short" ({run:v}) and "stout" ({pI':v}). Also, too much tee makes a person go "run and pee".

table.name: mem
table.column: The gas produced is called {SIp:n} (a general word for gas of any kind) or {Qep'It:n} (a gas produced within the body).[1] To distinguish between gas emission from different orifices, use a phrase involving {nuj:n}, {Hugh:n}, or {Sa'Hut:n:1}.[2]
From the Latin "eructare", or the English "eructation". The belch definition came from {HQ 12.4:src}[1]. It was expanded to also mean fart in a message to the {KLI mailing list:src}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city in {ghevchoq Sep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to controlling or handling something that can or may do something on its own (or due to some source of power), but the manual intervention causes it to do something else or behave differently. It is more likely to be used when the handling alters the configuration of the thing being manipulated, in comparison to {raQ:v:nolink} (which is used if the thing being handled doesn't do anything if it's not being handled). One might {ruQ:v:nolink} a robot vacuum cleaner by picking it up and reorienting it. One would not {ruQ:v:nolink} a {betleH:n} (unless it's an adjustable {betleH:n:nolink} of some sort). If one were to {ruQ:v:nolink} a work of art, that would suggest the artwork is manipulable in some way. Controlling the thrusters by pushing a button or two would be {raQ:v:nolink}, but manually controlling them by physically doing something to them directly, like yanking a thruster component, twisting something, or banging on something, would be {ruQ:v:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used to form similes, such as {puj verengan; bIQ rur@@puj:v, verengan:n, bIQ:n, rur:v} "the Ferengi is as weak as water".[2; 4] It can also be used to translate "like" in the sense of "looks like".[3]
Possibly a reference to the science fiction play R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) by Karel Čapek.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon penal colony, a planet mostly covered in ice. Prisoners are sent to work in its {tlhIlHalmey:n@@tlhIlHal:n, -mey:n}.
The name is based on Rorapandi, the penal colony island in the Disney movie "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea".

table.name: mem
table.column: He can sell ice on Rura Penthe.

table.name: mem
table.column: This describes a bond such as exists between blood brothers.

table.name: mem
table.column: be positively charged, have a positive charge
This was defined as "have a positive charge" in the {qep'a' 23 (2016):src} booklet, but was confirmed to be stative afterwards.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ritual that allows an orphan to join another House.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "sometimes" in {TKD:src} and as "occasionally" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to part of a computer input device (see {'eQway':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: be ready to collapse or die (referring to food)
This is an upper-class word to describe food that should be eaten live.
